paragraph.docTitle: A comprehensive review: Biological activity, modification and synthetic methodologies of prenylated flavonoids

&

subSection.paragraph: ARTICLE INFO
Prenylated flavonoids Biological activity
Synthesis
Structure–activity relationships
ABSTRACT

Prenylated flavonoids, a unique class of flavonoids which combine a flavonoid skeleton and a lipophilic prenyl side-chain, possess great potential biological activities including cytotoxicity, anti-inflammation, anti-Alzheimer, anti-microbial, anti-oxidant, anti-diabetes, estrogenic, vasorelaxant and enzyme inhibition. Recently, prenylated flavonoids have become an indispensable anchor for the development of new therapeutic agents, and have received increasing from medicinal chemists. The prenylated flavonoids have been outstanding developed through isolation, semi or fully synthesis in a very short period of time, which proves the great value in medicinal chemistry researches. In this review, research progress of prenylated flavonoids including natural prenylated flavonoids, structural modification, synthetic methodologies and pharmacological activities was summarized comprehensively. Furthermore, the structure–activity relationships (SARs) of prenylated flavonoids were summarized which provided a basis for the selective design and optimization of multifunctional prenylated flavonoid derivatives for the treatment of multi-factorial diseases in clinic.

Prenylated flavonoids are low molecular weight polyphenolic phytochemicals, which are characterized by the prenyl side chains in the flavonoid skeleton and derived from the secondary metabolism of plants ( Wang et al., 2001 ; Yang et al., 2014a , b). Prenylated flavonoids are mainly found in Moraceae , but also in other plant families, such as Fabaceae, Guttiferae , Cannabaceae , Rutaceae, Umbelliferae , Euphorbiaceae Asteraceae and Thymelaeaceae ( Botta et al., 2005 ; Marín et al., 2013 ; Yan et al., 2020 ; Yazaki et al., 2009 ). In the plants, the biosynthesis of prenylated flavonoids is achieved by inserting an active isoprenoid moiety called dimethylallyl diphosphate (DMAPP) into flavonoid skeletons including flavone, dihydroflavone, isoflavone, flavane and chalcone ( Chen et al., 2013 ), which is catalyzed by prenyltransferases, a class of enzymes that mainly acts on regulating the regio- and stereospecificity of the transferred prenyl group into the flavonoid skeleton, and contributes to the structural diversity of prenylated flavonoids in nature ( Li et al., 2015 ; Sasaki et al., 2008 ; Shen et al., 2012 ).

Prenylated flavonoids have higher lipophilicity than its skeleton flavonoids with nonprenylated forms, leading to a high affinity for Pglycoprotein in biological membranes. From this point of view, prenylated flavonoids may be a potent P-glycoprotein inhibitor, which is of great significance for improving the biological activities or pharmacological effects of flavonoids ( Basabe et al., 2010 ; Mukai et al., 2018). It has been reported that prenylated flavonoids have a variety of promising pharmacological properties, and are beneficial to human health by interacting with diverse cellular targets involved in crucial cellular signaling pathways in the body ( Marin et al., 2013 ; Nijveldt et al., 2001 ). In order to better explore or obtain prenylated flavonoids, it has become important goals to use structural modification strategies and explore effective methods to obtain prenylated flavonoids with more significant pharmacological activities. In the past few decades, the research in the field of prenylated flavonoids for drug discovery has attracted widespread attention from many researchers and pharmaceutical companies.

The objective of this review was to provide the pharmacological activities of prenylated flavonoids and their derivatives isolated from plants, semi or fully synthesized with different functional groups at different positions of their skeletons from 2000 to 2021. In addition, the structure–activity relationships (SARs) of prenylated flavonoids in terms of cytotoxicity, anti-inflammation, anti-Alzheimer, anti-microbial, antioxidant, anti-diabetes, estrogenic, vasorelaxant and enzyme inhibition were reviewed according to literature reports. Moreover, the regioselective syntheses methods of various prenylated flavonoids were also summarized in this paper.

subSection.paragraph:
Usually, human cancer cell line screening test is performed as the first step in the evaluation of chemicals for cancer prevention and treatment. Seven prenylated flavones, compounds ( 1–7 ) ( Fig. 3 ) ( Table 1 ) were evaluated for cytotoxicity against several human cell lines in vitro, the outcome indicated that the cytotoxic effect varied from strong to moderate, and particularly, artelastin ( 1 ) possessed three prenyl side-chain substitutions of the A and C ring at position 3, 6 and 8, respectively, showing the most potent activity with IC 50 < 5 μM against three human cell lines including MCF-7, TK-10 and UACC-62, doxorubin was used as the positive controls with IC 50 values of 5.5, 57.0 and 9.4 μM, respectively ( Cidade et al., 2001 ; Pedro et al., 2004 , 2005 ). Similarly, five diprenylated flavonol broussonols A-E ( 8–12 ) were isolated from the leaves of
Broussonetia kazinoki (Moraceae)
and their cytotoxicity against several different cell lines was measured in a MTT test, the result showed that broussonol D ( 11 ) had the strongest cytotoxic activity against KB human tumor cells with IC 50 value of 4.15 μM ( Zhang et al., 2001 ). Several years later, a series of flavonol and hihydroflavonol derivatives ( 13–19 ) were obtained from the
Artocarpus elasticus (Moraceae)
and
Macaranga recurvate (Euphorbiaceaae)
, among these compounds, artoindonesianin ( 13 ) and artonin E ( 14 ) with a double bond between C-2 and C-3, and bearing a prenyl side-chain at the C-3 position additionally, which were reported to have marked cytotoxic activity against the murine leukemia P388 cell line with IC 50 value of 0.2 and 0.06 μg/ml, respectively, and the results indicated that the prenyl side-chain at the C-3 position of prenylated flavones would promote its antitumor activity ( Hakim et al., 2006 ; Etti et al., 2017 ; Tanjung, 2012 ).

caption.paragraph: Fig. 3. ( continued ).
Fig. 3. ( continued ).

subSection.paragraph:
Soon afterwards, a series of prenylated flavonoids ( 20–27 ) were isolated from
Macaranga kurzii (Euphorbiaceae)
and
Macaranga indica (Euphorbiaceaae)
, and their cytotoxicity against A549 and Hep G2 cancer cell lines were evaluated. However, most of the compounds did not possess obvious cytotoxicity against these cancer cell lines ( Yang et al., 2014a , b; Yang et al., 2015a , b). Daphnegiravone D ( 28 ) is a typical diprenyl flavone isolated from
Daphne giraldii (Euphorbiaceaae)
by our research group, which bearing the prenyl side chain position at C-8 on the A ring and C-3 ′ on the B ring, respectively ( Wang et al., 2017a , b). The cytotoxic activities in vitro of daphnegiravone D against nine human cancer cell lines and one normal hepatic cell line were evaluated by using MTT assay with 5-Fluorouracil as positive control. And the result indicated that daphnegiravone D exhibited potent cytotoxicity in a concentration and time-dependent manner against human hepatoma Hep3B and HepG2 cells with IC 50 values of 1.63 μM and 9.89 μM, respectively, but exhibited no apparent cytotoxicity on human normal cells. The subsequent mechanism study suggested that daphnegiravone D could arrest cell cycle at G0/G1 phase and induce apoptosis through regulating p38 and JNK/MAPK pathways in Hep3B and HepG2 cells. Moreover, in vivo studies demonstrated that daphnegiravone D could significantly inhibit tumor growth in a nude mouse xenograft model by suppressing the proliferation of tumor cells. In addition, a chemical study on the leaves of
Epimedium Koreanum Nakai
have resulted in the discovery of several prenylated flavones ( Zhang et al., 2018 ). Subsequently, MTT assays showed that epimedokoreanin B ( 30 ) exhibited the most potent cytotoxicity against lung cancer A549 and NCIH292 cells among these prenylated flavones with IC 50 value of 5.6 and 7.9 μM, respectively, in contrast, baohuoside I ( 29 ) showed almost nontoxic activity with IC 50 > 50 μM. Comparing the structures of these compounds, it was suggested that the position of prenyl, hydroxyl and glycosyl groups within the flavonoids played a critical role in the viability inhibitory effects of lung cancer cells. Glycosylation of the flavonoid and hydroxylation of the prenyl side chain decreased the cytotoxicity of the compounds, which might be related to the increasing of hydrophilicity of the prenylated flavonoids.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 3. ( continued ).

subSection.paragraph:
Similarly, 20 prenylated flavonoids ( 33–52 ) ( Fig. 3 ) ( Table 1 ) have been isolated from the plants of
Morus nigra (Moraceae)
,
Epimedium brevicornu (Berberidaceae)
and
Sinopodophyllum hexandrum (Berberidaceae)
. MTT assays showed that most of the compounds had no apparent cytotoxicity on six human cancer cell lines including HL-60, SMMC-772, A-549, MCF-7, SW-480 and HepG2. Fortunately, kuwanon C ( 33 ), epimedonin L ( 35 ) and sinoflavonoids U ( 42 ) possessing the same prenyl side chain at C-8, 5,7-dihydroxy substitution on the A ring showed the most potent cytotoxic activities against MCF-7 and HepG2 cell lines with IC 50 values of 3.83–9.54 μM ( Bar et al., 2019 ; Ren et al., 2018 ; Sun et al., 2019 ). In addition, 19 prenylated flavonoids ( 53–71 ) were reported from the plants Sinopodophylli
Fructus (Berberidaceae)
,
Macaranga adenantha (Euphorbiaceaae)
,
Sophora flavescens (Fabaceae)
,
Berchemia discolor (Rhamnaceae)
,
Dalbergia velutina (Fabaceae)
and
Maackia amurensis (Fabaceae)
( Tanjung, 2012 ; Chin et al., 2006 ; Yang et al., 2015a ; Jung et al., 2011 ; Kaennakam et al., 2016 ; Li et al., 2009 ; Veselova et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2017a ), and their cytotoxicity against several human cancer cell lines were tested by the MTT method in vitro. Unfortunately, expect for sinopodophyllines B ( 54 ), most of compounds exhibited weak activity with IC 50 > 50 μM. It was worth noting that sinopodophyllines B with IC 50 values of 1.5 μM against T47D cancer cells, whose structure was very similar to sinopodophyllines A ( 53 ) (IC 50 > 100 μM), but their activity has a big difference, which indicated that the prenyl side chain at position C-8 was crucial for prenylated flavonoids’ cytotoxicity against cancer cells, and cyclization of the C-8 prenyl side chain with 7-OH would dramatically decrease the antitumor activity. In addition, 3 ′ ,4 ′ -dihydroxyl moiety on the B ring also played an important role for prenylated flavonoids’ cytotoxicity against cancer cells.

A phytochemical study on the leaves of
Morus alba (Moraceae)
led to the isolation of 9 prenylated flavonoids ( 72–80 ) ( Fig. 3 ), and MTT assays showed that these isolates exhibited potent cytotoxicity against HeLa and MCF-7 cell lines with IC 50 values in the range of 0.64–7.88 μM ( Table 1 ) ( Dat et al., 2010 ). Particularly, morusin ( 79 ) exhibited the most potent cytotoxicity against HeLa cells among these compounds with IC 50 value of 0.64 μM. Comparing the structures of these compounds and their cytotoxicity, 3 ′ -geranyl-3-prenyl-2 ′ ,4 ′ ,5,7-tetrahydroxyflavone ( 72 ) and morusin ( 79 ) featuring an additional prenyl side chain at position C-3 exhibited more potent cytotoxicity than kuwanon S ( 73 ) and atalantoflavone ( 80 ), respectively, which also suggested that the prenyl side chain at position C-3 may contribute to its cytotoxicity against human cancer cells. Similarly, six prenylated flavonoids ( 81–86 ) ( Fig. 3 ) were isolated from the leaves of
Derris malaccensis (Fabaceae)
, and the cytotoxic activity of these compounds against a panel of cancer cell lines was evaluated by a quantitative cytotoxic assay ( Table 1 ) ( Chokchaichamnankit et al., 2011 ). The result indicated that pomiferin ( 83 ) containing the 3 ′ ,4 ′ -dihydroxyl moiety exhibited more potent cytotoxic activity against MDA-MB231 and T47D than that of osajin ( 82 ) or warangalone ( 84 ), which has the 4-monohydroxyl moiety. However, when the 4 ′ -hydroxyl group was methylated, the cytotoxicity of the compound ( 81 ) against MDA-MB231 and T47D was lower than that of pomiferin ( 83 ). In addition, a series of prenylated flavonoids ( 87–122 ) ( Fig. 3 ) were obtained from the plants of
Macaranga denticulate (Euphorbiaceaae)
,
Sinopodophyllum emodi (Berberidaceae)
,
Macaranga adenantha (Euphorbiaceaae)
,
Commiphora opobalsamum (Burseraceae)
,
Epimedium brevicornu (Berberidaceae)
,
Macaranga indica (Euphorbiaceaae)
,
Macaranga balansae (Euphorbiaceaae)
and
Sophora pachycarpa (Fabaceae)
( Basabe et al., 2010 ; Boozari et al., 2019 ; Yang et al., 2015a , b; El-Gamal et al., 2017 ; Huon Ga et al., 2019; Mai et al., 2019 ; Pang et al., 2017a , b; Sun et al., 2015 ). MTT assays showed that most of compounds had no apparent cytotoxicity with IC 50 > 10 μM ( Table 1 ). However, alopecurone J ( 121 ) containing the lavandulyl moiety on C-8 exhibited obvious cytotoxicity against MCF-7 cell line with IC 50 value of 8.25 μM, and 6,8-Diprenyl-4-methyl-naringenin ( 116 ) with prenyl moiety on C-6 and C-8, respectively, showed apparent cytotoxicity against Pan C1 cell line with IC 50 value of 7.89 μM.

caption.paragraph: Occurrence and cytotoxicity activity of prenylated flavonoids.

subSection.paragraph: In addition, MTT assays showed that the synthetic icaritin derivatives ( 231–272 ) ( Figs. 6 and 7 ) had (MDR) reversal activities implicating them as potential MCF-7/MDR reversal agents ( Chen et al., 2015 ; Liu et al., 2019 ). While the derivatives 237–272 are carboxylic acid or carboxylic conjugates, and their cytotoxic activities were evaluated against three cancer cell lines including MDA-MB-435s, MCF-7 and A549, and the result indicated that the derivatives 244 (IC 50 = 4.7 μM), 246 (IC 50 = 3.0 μM), 270 (IC 50 = 3.0 μM) and 272 (IC 50 = 2.2 μM) showed significant cytotoxicity against MCF-7 breast cancer cells than that parent compound icaritin (IC 50 = 7.0 μM) ( Table 4 ). Moreover, it was worth mentioning that derivatives 270 and 272 exhibited not only good selectivity towards MCF-7 cells, but also relatively lower cytotoxicity against normal cells. Based on these data, structure activity relationship analysis indicates that mono-substitution at either C-3 or C-7 hydroxyl group of icaritin could improve the cytotoxicity of icaritin, and the C-3 hydroxyl group might be a preferable chemical modification site for the development of icaritin as the anti-tumor drugs.

The relationship between the structures of prenylated flavonoids and cytotoxic activities on human cancer cells indicates the following common structures: (a) the prenyl side chain position at C-8 on the A ring of prenylated flavonoids could be a crucial active unit, and cyclization or hydroxylation of the prenyl side chain would dramatically decrease cytotoxicity (compound 1 vs 5 , 30 vs 32 , 42 vs 48 , 54 vs 53 , 42 vs 45 ); (b) the prenyl side chain present C-3 at C ring of prenylated flavonoids, could significantly improve cytotoxicity (compound 72 vs 73 ); (c) featuring a prenyl side chain present C-8 at A ring and C-3 ′ at B ring, respectively, may lead to the most potent cytotoxic lead compound (compounds 33 and 77 ); (d) glycosylation of 3-OH at C ring of prenylated flavonoids or hydroxylation of the prenyl side chain could decrease cytotoxicity a lot (compound 30 vs 29 and 31 ) ( Fig. 8 ).

A series of prenylated flavonoids and its derivatives ( 11 , 79 , 80 , 273–291 ) ( Figs. 3 and 9 ) were obtained and their anti-inflammatory activity was tested ( Table 5 ) (Han´akova´et al., 2017; Hoˇsek et al., 2011; Kim et al., 2002 ; Ko et al., 2021 ; Nishikawa et al., 2020 ; Owor et al., 2020 ; Ryu et al., 2019 ; Shahinozzaman et al., 2018 ; Wu et al., 2018 ). The results showed that most of prenylated flavonoids possessed moderate anti-inflammatory activity in LPS-stimulated RAW 264.7 cells through down-regulated COX-2 induction at 10–25 μM. Particularly, cudraflavone B ( 282) is a prenylated flavonoid containing a cyclized prenyl group on the ring A, bearing an additional 2 ′ ,4 ′ -OH moiety on the ring B, which exhibited the most potent anti-inflammatory activity via inhibiting the activity of COX-2. This effect is comparable to that of the typical COX inhibitor indomethacin (COX-2, IC 50 = 2.5 μM for compound 282 and 1.9 μM for indomethacin), showing that compound 282 is a strong COX-2 inhibitor and has some potential as a new nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug lead. Based on these data, the SARs displayed the position of a cyclic prenyl side chain on the ring A and 2 ′ ,4 ′ -OH moiety on the ring B of prenylated flavonoid skeleton, which played an important role for anti-COX activity.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 6. Synthesis of potential MDR reversal icariin derivatives ( 231–236 ). Reagents and conditions: (a) H 2 SO 4 (2–5 equiv), 90% EtOH, reflux; 1.5 h; (b) 20% H 2 SO 4 , MeOH, reflux, 2 h; (c) 20% H SO, MeOH, 25 ◦ C, 4 h; (d) ClSO CH, Et N, 4 h, then HCl; (e) ClSO CH, pyridine, 0 ◦ C, 3 h; then HCl; (f) ClSO NH, DMA, CH Cl, 2 4 2 3 3 2 3 2 2 2 2 0 ◦ C, 3 h; (g) ClSO H, Et N, 0 ◦ C, 3 h; then HCl.

Fig. 7. Synthesis of icaritin derivatives ( 237–272 ). Reagents and conditions: i. bromo-carboxylic acid ethyl esters (2.5–4.0 equiv.), acetone, K 2 CO 3 , reflux, 6 h; ii. bromo-carboxylic acid ethyl esters (1.0–1.5 equiv.), acetone, K 2 CO 3 , reflux, 6 h; iii. NaOH, MeOH/H 2 O (2:1), rt, 4 h; iv. glutaric anhydride, DMAP, TEA, DCM, rt, 8 h.

subSection.paragraph:
In 2011, Jeran et al. reported that 5,7,4 ′ -trihydroxy-6-geranylflavanone ( 292 ) ( Fig. 9 ), a prenylated flavonoid derivative isolated from the fruits of
Artocarpus commun
is ( Moraceae ), showed a great anti-inflammatory property in vitro ( Jer et al., 2011 ). According to their study, low concentration of compound 292 (≤2.5 μM) showed a great inhibitory effect on gene expression of RAGE, and down-regulated both TNF-α and IL-1β secretion and gene expression in THP-1 cells. Podoverine B ( 293 ) ( Fig. 9 ), a prenylated flavanone-flavonol dimer isolated from plant callus culture, and exhibited potent anti-inflammatory activity through inhibition of macrophage chemiluminescence (IC 50 = 6.4 μM) ( Kim et al., 2006 ). Additionally, the production of a typical pro-inflammatory cytokine TNF-α in LPS stimulated macrophages was used to determine the anti-inflammatory activity of prenylated flavonoids ( 33 , 283 , 294–319 ) ( Fig. 9 ) ( Table 5 ) (Han´akova´et al., 2015, 2017; Zelova´et al., 2014). The outcome exhibited that compounds 283 and 294–297 were most efficient in significantly inhibiting the secretion of TNF-α. More importantly, compound 296 (IC 50 < 10 μM) displayed the strongest inhibitory activity with an effect nearly twice that of the positive control prednisone.

Thus, 39 natural prenylated flavonoids and its derivatives ( 320–358 ) ( Fig. 9 ) ( Table 5 ) were evaluated for their inhibitory activity on NO production in RAW 264.7 mouse macrophage cells ( Cao et al., 2016 ; Huan et al., 2017 ; Jin et al., 2014 ; Anh et al., 2019; Liu et al., 2019 ; Su et al., 2016 ). The result indicated that compounds 331 and 332 containing two prenyl side chain on the rings A and B, respectively, and exhibited significantly inhibitory activity against NO production with IC 50 values of 16.8 and 19.7 μM, respectively ( Jin et al., 2014 ). In addition, compound 340 containing a cyclized-geranyl group on the position C-6 could significantly inhibit NO production with IC 50 values of 6.7 μM, which was more potent than the positive control pyrrolidine dithiocarbamate (IC 50 = 10.8 μM). Moreover, to our surprise, the result indicated that prenylated flavonoids derivatives ( 354–358 ) exhibited remarkable inhibitory effects against NO production with the IC 50 values ranging from 0.89 ± 0.05 to 8.49 ± 0.18 μM. And their structure possessed a prenyl side chain on the ring A, and one or two hydroxyl group were positioned on the ring B of the skeleton of prenylated flavonoid ( Liu et al., 2019 ).

caption.paragraph: Table 4 Cytotoxic activity (IC 50, μM) of synthesized compounds.

paragraph.tableNote: a nt: not tested. b Positive control.

subSection.paragraph: In a recent study, Yongsheng Chen and co-workers semi-synthesized the rare prenylated flavonoid isolaxifolin ( 369 ) through the five-step reaction sequences ( Fig. 10 ), with the natural apigenin as the starting material ( Chen et al., 2019 ). They investigated the impact of compound 369 at five concentrations up to 6.2 μM on certain pro-inflammatory cytokines in murine macrophage RAW 264.7 cells, and the result showed that compound 369 could reduce the secretion of NO, TNF-α, and IL- 6 in a dose-independent manner.

Aforementioned outcome suggested that the relationship between the structure of prenylated flavonoids and anti-inflammatory activity indicates the following common structures: (a) the keto group at position C-4, and the hydroxy groups at positions C-5, C-7, and C-4 ′ of the prenyl flavonoid skeleton are important structural elements for anti-inflammatory activity; (b) the double bond between C-2 and C-3 does not have a great effect on the anti-inflammatory activity (compounds 33 , 273 , 287–289 and 292 ); (c) the cyclization of the prenyl moiety in C-6 or C-8 also can contribute the inhibitory activity against the COX, TNF-α and NO production (compounds 282 , 296 and 341 ); (d) two prenyl side chains positioned on ring A and C, respectively, exhibit the most potent anti-inflammatory activity (compounds 33 , 282 and 296 ); (e) the prenylated isoflavones have remarkable inhibitory activity against NO production, and the methoxy group at position C-7 is beneficial to increase the activity (compounds 354–358 ) ( Fig. 11 ).

subSection.paragraph:
It is well known that plants could produce a variety of chemicals to survive attacks by microbial invasion. Five prenylated flavonoids ( 388–392 ) ( Fig. 13 ) ( Table 7 ) were isolated from the stems and roots of
Tripterygium wilfordii
(Celastraceae) and screened for antibacterial effects against several bacterial strains such as Cryptococcus neoformans , Pseudomonas aeruginosa , vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus faecalis , methicillinresistant Staphylococcus aureus, and Staphylococcus aureus , which was done using modified versions of the NCCLS methods (
Chen et al., 2017
). The results indicated that these prenylated flavonoids possessed promising antimicrobial activity (IC 50 < 5.0 μg/ml). Particularly, compounds
389
and 392 exhibited more potent antimicrobial activity against C. neoformans with IC 50 values of 2.95 μg/mL and 1.06 μg/mL, respectively. In addition , compound
383
was especially active against MRSA (IC 50 values of 2.07 and 2.60 μg/mL, respectively) and S. aureus (2.01 and 2.16 μg/mL, respectively).

Moreover, icaritin, is an excellent natural scaffold for further modification to obtain more effective derivatives. Several new series of icaritin derivatives ( 393–412 ) were designed and synthesized by the Liu group ( Figs. 14 , 15 ) ( Lin et al., 2017 ). The antibacterial effects of these derivatives were tested in Mueller-Hinton broth by standard broth microdilution methods, and the result ( Table 8 ) indicated that most of derivatives were more active against four Gram-positive bacterial strains, including MRSA,
Staphylococcus aureus
and
Bacillus cereus
. Among them, compound 396 , containing two arginine residues, was the most active of all the tested compounds with MICs values ranging from 1.56 to 3.13 μg/mL. In addition, compound 396 also exhibited potent in vivo antimicrobial activity in the
S.aureus
29213-infected mouse keratitis model, with comparable capability as the positive control levofloxacin. Based on these data, it was suggested that the greatest improvement in antimicrobial activity was attributed to the strong electrostatic interaction between the compounds which bearing positively charged groups and the negatively charged bacterial membrane.

subSection.paragraph:
Haruki Yamada and co-workers have been screening antimalarial activity against the multi-drug-resistant
Plasmodium falciparum
of the medicinal plants, and they demonstrated that five prenylated flavonoids ( 413–417) ( Fig. 13 ) from the stem bark of
Erythrina fusca (Leguminosae)
showed a good antimalarial activity which was conducted using the multi-drug-resistant (K1) and sensitive (FCR3) strains of
P.falciparum
( Table 7 ) ( Khaomek et al., 2008 ). Among them, compounds 416 exhibited the most potent activity with IC 50 values of 1.6 μg/ml, while compounds 413 and 415 did not exhibit such significant activity, even though the structures of these compounds also possess the same prenyl group. This result suggested that the position of prenylation rather than the number of prenyl groups determines to the construction of more potent antimalarial agents.

Similarly, a series of prenylated flavonoids ( 418–430 ) ( Fig. 13 ) was isolated from
Erythrina latissima (Leguminosae)
and tested for their antiplasmodial activity against
P.falciparum
strain K1 ( Table 7 ) ( Tuenter et al., 2019 ). The result indicated that most of compounds showed a moderate potent activity, and compounds 420 , 424 , 425 , 427 and 430 contained underivatised prenyl substituents and exhibited remarkable biological activities with IC 50 values of < 5 μM. The structure-activity relationship indicated that the underivatised prenyl substituents at the flavonoid skeleton contribute to more potent antiplasmodial activity than the prenyl side chain is converted to a 6-membered ring.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 13. Chemical structures of prenylated flavonoids with antimicrobial activity ( 388–430 ).
Occurrence and antimicrobial activity of prenylated flavonoids.

subSection.paragraph:
Xiuli Zhang and co-workers systematically evaluated the antioxidant activity of xanthohumol ( 431 ) ( Fig. 16 ), the major prenylated flavonoid in beer, using three systems including ABTS •+ , DPPH, and FRAP assays ( Table 9 ) ( Zhang et al., 2014 ). The result showed xanthohumol exhibited remarkable antioxidant activity in the ABTS •+ and FRAP assays with TEAC (Trolox as equivalent antioxidant capacity) values of 0.31 and 0.27 μM/L, respectively. From the study of Jan Hosek and co-workers, the natural prenylated flavonoids ( 82 , 287 , 432–433 ) ( Figs. 3 ,
9
, 16 ) were also screened for their scavenging activity against three reactive oxygen species (O 2 • , H 2 O 2 , and HClO) ( Hoek et al., 2013 ). Among these compounds, compound 287 contained two hydroxyl moieties at positions C-3 ′ and C-4 ′ on the B-ring, and exhibited the highest level of scavenging activity against superoxide radicals and hydrogen peroxide with IC 50 values of 41.2 ± 3.7 and 554.0 ± 45.8 μM, respectively. The outcome demonstrated that bearing the catechol moiety on the B-ring of prenylated flavonoids significantly improved the antioxidant activity.

In order to search for natural products which can be used for scavenging free radicals, Wen-Chun Lan et al. obtained a series of prenylated flavonoids ( 78 , 329 , 434–444 ) ( Figs. 3 , 9 , 16 ) from
Artocarpus altilis (Moraceae)
and tested their free radical-scavenging activities through ABTS •+ , O 2 • , and DPPH assays ( Lan et al., 2013 ). Unfortunately, the result indicated that most compounds showed either moderate or no scavenging effects. Compounds 436 and 444 whose structures possess two or three hydroxyl group substituents on the B-ring, exhibited the better radical-scavenging activities, and antioxidant activity is ranked as follows: 436 > 444 Based on these data, the SAR outcome revealed that as the number of hydroxyl groups on the B-ring increased, the scavenging effects of prenylated flavonoids also increased. Moreover, two hydroxyl groups adjacent to each other showed the better scavenging effects.

subSection.paragraph:
Several prenylated flavonoids ( 445–451 ) ( Fig. 17 ) was isolated from the roots of
Dorstenia psilurus (Moraceae)
, and their α- glucosidase inhibitory activity was evaluated by using the slightly modified method of Matsu et al. ( Table 10 ) ( Tabopda et al., 2008 ). Among them, compound 445 with three unmodified prenyl groups exhibited the best α- glucosidase inhibitory activity (IC 50 = 4.13 μM), while compound 450 , with only one prenyl group, showed the worst α- glucosidase inhibitory activity (IC 50 = 43.95 μM). It was observed that α- glucosidase inhibitory activity increased with the number of unmodified prenylated groups present, which suggested that the prenyl side chain could be important for α- glucosidase inhibitory activity. In addition, a series of prenylated flavonoids ( 370 , 452–465 ) ( Figs. 12 and 17 ) and other compounds were isolated from Herba Epimedii ( Berberidaceae ), subsequently, the PPAR-γ ligand binding activity of these isolates was evaluated by using a GAL-4-PPAR-γ chimera assay system ( Tantry et al., 2012 ). The result indicated that these prenylated flavonoids exhibited more potent activity than other isolates, which implied that prenyl units has been linked to an increased affinity to the PPAR-γ.

Prenylated flavonoids represent one of the largest groups of phytoestrogens, not only with a chemical structure resembles 17β- estradiol but also the ability to mimic estrogen activity ( Oh et al., 2006 ). Two prenylated flavonoids named glabrene ( 466 ) and glabridin ( 467 ) ( Fig. 17 ) were isolated from
Glycyrrhiza glabra (Fabaceae)
by Rudy Simons et al. (2011) . The estrogen-like activities of both compounds have been tested by three systems including competitive ligand binding assays in vitro cell assays and in vivo animal models. The outcome indicated that compounds 466 and 467 bind with the estrogen receptor closely, with EC 50 values of 5 × 10 5 M and 5 × 10 6 M, respectively ( Table 11 ).

In addition, four prenylated flavonoids 468–471 ( Fig. 18 ) were synthesized and exhibited significantly estrogen-like activity in MCF-7/ BOS cells. However, the specific inhibition rates or IC 50 was not provided in the reference, and the estrogenic potency of these compounds is ranked as follows: 469 > 471 > 470 > 468 . The outcome suggested compounds 469 and 470 contained the prenyl moiety at C-8 whose estrogen-like activity was more potent than compound 468 containing the prenyl moiety at C-6, which revealed that the 8-prenyl substituent could markedly improve the estrogenic activity ( Hajirahimkhan et al., 2018 ). According to these data, it was observed that the location of prenyl group at ring A of flavonoids could significantly affect the osteogenic activity. In particularly, the prenylflavonoids with C-8 prenylation may represent a class of flavonoids with a higher osteogenic activity.

caption.paragraph: Occurrence and estrogenic activity of prenylated flavonoids.

subSection.paragraph: Some prenylated flavonoids and their derivatives 472–494 ( Fig. 19 ) were designed and synthesized by the Yongzhou Hu and co-workers according to the predictive results of support vector machine (SVM) classification model, and their vasodilatory activity were evaluated against phenylephrine (PE)-induced contraction in rat thoracic aorta rings model ( Dong et al., 2008 , 2009 ). Among these compounds, compounds 483 , 485 and 493 exhibited potent vasorelaxant activity. Particularly, (±) leachianone G 483 which bearing 8-prenyl on the A ring and 2 ′ ,4’-(OH) 2 on the B ring exhibited the most potent vasorelaxant activity (EC 50 : 9.3 μM, Emax: 94.9%). SAR studies of prenylated flavonoids revealed that flavanones showed the most potent vasorelaxant activity, while flavones and chalcones exhibited medium activity. In addition, existence of prenyl group at A-ring and 2 ′ ,4’-(OH) 2 substitution at B-ring contributed to a better vasorelaxant activity.

The tyrosinase inhibitory activity of nine prenylated flavonoids ( 12 , 33 , 77 , 495–499 ) ( Figs. 3 and 20 ) ( Table 12 ) was evaluated ( Jin et al., 2010 ; Lee et al., 2004 ; Zhang et al., 2016 ). The outcome indicated that compounds 12 , 33, 498, 499 showed considerable inhibitory activity, and particularly, compound 498 was revealed as a potent inhibitor (IC 50 = 7.3 μM), compared to the positive control kojic acid (IC 50 = 24.8 μM), which suggested that the presence of a hydroxy group at positions C-5 and C-7 on ring-A seems to contribute significantly to the tyrosinase inhibitory activity. In addition, a series of prenylated flavones, compounds 78 , 329 , 434–444 ( Figs. 3 , 9 , 16 ) were also evaluated for their inhibitory effects on mushroom tyrosinase, unfortunately, most of these compounds were not active with IC 50 > 100 μM ( Lan et al., 2013 ). In a recent study, serveral prenylated flavonoids ( 500–506 ) ( Fig. 20 ) ( Table 12 ) were isolated from the leaves of
Morus yunnanensis (Moraceae)
and their tyrosinase inhibitory activity was evaluated by using the spectrophotometric method ( Xiao et al., 2012 ). Among these compounds, compounds 502 , 503 and 504 showed potent inhibitory activity with IC 50 values ranging from 0.12 ± 0.02 to 1.43 ± 0.43 μM. Particularly, it was worth noting that the IC 50 value of compound 503 (0.15 μM) was 217-fold lower than the kojic acid (32.62 μM). Based on these data, prenylated flavonoids bearing the 2 ′ ,4’-(OH) 2 on the B ring seems crucial to the tyrosinase inhibitory activity.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 18. Synthesis of prenylated flavonoids ( 468–471 ). Reagents and conditions: (a) 1.3 N NaOH, acetone; 3,3-dimethylallyl bromide, benzene, reflux; (b) 3,3-dimethylallyl bromide, 10% KOH; (c) MOMCl, K CO, acetone, 0 ◦ C to RT; (d) p -methoxymethoxyl benzaldehyde, 10% KOH (H O/EtOH); (e) NaOAc, EtOH, reflux; (f) 3N 2 3 2 HCl, MeOH, reflux; (g) I, pyridine, 90 ◦ C.

Fig. 19. Synthesis of prenylated flavonoids 472–494 Reagents and conditions: (a): 3,3-dimethylallyl bromide, 10% KOH; (b): MOMCl, K CO, acetone, 0 ◦ C - RT; (c): 2 3 corresponding benzaldehyde, 10% KOH ethanol/H O, RT; (d): 5% HCl, MeOH/THF, reflux; (e) NaOAc, EtOH, reflux; (f) I, pyridine, 90 ◦ C.

subSection.paragraph:
3 ′ ,5 ′ -cyclic monophosphate (cGMP) and phosphodiesterase 5 (PDE5) play a significant role in modulating smooth muscle tone in general, and the inhibitors of cGMP PDE5 have greater efficacy for the treatment of erectile dysfunction ( Tabopda et al., 2008 ). During the search for cGMP-PDE5 inhibitors, Tabopda et al. found that the extracts from
Sophora flavescens (Leguminosae)
exhibited potent inhibitory activity, and they obtained five prenylated flavonoids ( 516–520 ) ( Fig. 20 ) from the plants, subsequently their inhibitory activity against cGMP-PDE5 was evaluated ( Table 12 ) ( Tabopda et al., 2008 ). The result indicated that these compounds exhibited potent cGMP-PDE5 inhibitory activity with IC 50 values ranging from 0.03 to 10.6 μM. It was worth noting that sophoflavescenol ( 519 ), a C-8 prenylated flavonol, showed the most potent inhibitory activity (IC 50 = 0.013 μM) against cGMP-PDE5, which suggested that the prenylated flavonoids can be considered as a lead structure for the future synthesis of potent cGMP-PDE5 inhibitors with probably more desirable pharmacological profiles.

Neuraminidase mainly promote mucosal infection via biofilm formation which is closely related to bacterial infection, and it also appears to be a proven target in anti-viral drug development ( Soong et al., 2006 ; Kim et al., 2011a ). Four prenylated flavanones ( 521–524 ) ( Fig. 20 ) were isolated from the extract of
Amorpha fruticose (Leguminosae)
and exhibited strong inhibitory activity against neuraminidase with IC 50 values ranging from 0.12 to 22.03 μM ( Table 12 ) ( Soong et al., 2006 ). Moreover, amorisin ( 522 ) bearing 6,7,5 ′ -triisoprenyl and 5,7,3 ′ ,4 ′ -tetrahydroxyl moiety, showed the highest inhibition (IC 50 = 0.12 μM), which was 30-fold more potent than the positive control quercetin (IC 50 = 3.46 μM). The SAR outcome uncovered that the hydroxy groups at positions C-3 ′ and C-4 ′ of prenylated flavanone skeleton played a crucial role in the neuraminidase inhibitory activity. In addition, several prenylated flavonoids and its derivatives ( 370 , 525–530 ) ( Figs. 12 and 20 ) ( Table 12 ) have been isolated from the leaves of
Epimedium koreanum Nakai (Berberidaceae)
and exhibited a significant inhibition to the neuraminidase ( Choi et al., 2019 ). In particularly, epimedokoreanin B ( 525 ) with the flavonoid skeleton of luteolin, additionally, two prenyl groups were positioned at C-8 and C-3 ′ , respectively, and showed the most potent inhibitory activity with IC 50 value of 0.17 μM, which was 500 times more effective than luteolin (IC 50 = 85.6 μM). It was observed that the prenyl groups were crucial for the neuraminidase inhibitory activities of these compounds.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 20. Chemical structures of prenylated flavonoids with enzyme inhibitory activity ( 495–550 ).
Fig. 20. ( continued ).
Fig. 20. ( continued ).

subSection.paragraph:
The indoleamine 2,3-dioxygenase 1 (IDO1), a tryptophan catabolising enzyme, is known as a tumour cell survival factor that can cause immune escape in several types of cancer. Therefore, the development of IDO1 inhibitors has attracted more and more attention from researchers ( Kwon et al., 2019 ). Six prenylated flavonoids ( 531–536 ) ( Fig. 20 ) were obtained from
Sophora flavescens (Fabaceae)
and their IDO1 inhibitory activity was evaluated ( Table 12 ) ( Kwon et al., 2019 ). Among these compounds, 536 with two prenyl side chain at position C-6 and C-8 respectively, showed the strongest inhibitory effects with IC 50 values of 4.3 μM, and the subsequent molecular docking analysis also revealed that the prenyl residues of compound 536 had binding affinity to residues of IDO1. Thus, the prenyl side chain at the skeleton of prenylated flavonoids could be important for IDO1 inhibitory activity.

The phosphodiesterases (PDEs) mainly catalyze the hydrolysis of the cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) and cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP) ( Bender et al., 2006 ). Given the critical roles of cAMP and cGMP in physiologic processes, PDEs has become an important drug target for treatment of various diseases such as congestive heart failure, pulmonary hypertension and schizophrenia ( Keravis et al., 2011 ). A series of prenylated flavonoids ( 33 , 537–550 ) ( Figs. 3 and 20 ) was isolated from the traditional Chinese medicine
Morus alba (Moraceae)
, and their inhibitory activity against phosphodiesterase-4 (PDE4) was evaluated ( Table 13 ) ( Guo et al., 2017 ). The result indicated that most of these isolates showed remarkable inhibitory activity against PDE4 with IC 50 values ranging from 0.0054 to 0.40 μM, which was more potent than the positive control rolipram (IC 50 = 0.62 μM). Particularly, compound 537 exhibited the most potent inhibitory activity with IC 50 value of 0.0054 μM, and molecular dynamics simulations revealed that the prenyl moiety could be an important pharmacophore to improve the activity. Furthermore, in order to construct a small prenylated flavonoid library for the structure-activity relationship (SAR) study, compound 79 , the major component in the
Morus alba (Moraceae)
and obtained in large amount, served as the starting material to semi-synthesize its derivatives. A total of 13 derivatives ( 551–563 ) were synthesized through methylation, esterification, hydrogenation, silanization and oxidative cyclization ( Fig. 21 ) ( Guo et al., 2017 ). Unfortunately, the result indicated that most derivatives were less active than the parent compound 79 ( Table 13 ). For PDE4, the key SARs which dramatically improved the activities could be summarized. (a) presence of prenyl moiety at C-3 and C-8 seems to be more contribute to the significant inhibitory activity (compounds 33 , 537–540 , 543 , 545 and 549 ); (b) formation of 2 H -pyran ring D between C-9 and 2 ′ -OH promotes the improvement of activity (compounds 537 and 538 vs 79 ).

The initial relationship between the structure of prenylated flavonoids and enzyme inhibition activity indicates the following common structures: (a) presence of the 2 ′ ,4 ′ -OH moiety on the B ring can significantly improve the tyrosinase inhibitory activity, but the keto group at position C-4 does not have a great effect on the tyrosinase inhibition (compounds 502 and 503 ); (b) the double bond between C-2 and C-3 are important structural elements for cGMP-PDE5 inhibitory activity (compounds 519 vs 516–518 ); (c) the 3 ′ ,4 ′ -OH moiety of the prenyl flavonoid skeleton are important structural elements for neuraminidase inhibition (compounds 522 vs 523, 525 vs 527 ); (d) formation of 2 H -pyran ring between 3-prenyl moiety and 2 ′ -OH can significantly increase the PDE4 inhibition activity (compounds 537 and 538 vs 79 ) ( Fig. 22 ).

heading.emphasis: 4.1. Total synthesis of A-ring prenylated flavonoids

subSection.paragraph:
Up to now, most of the prenylated flavonoids with one or two prenyl side-chain on the A ring can be synthesized by various synthetic schemes. Van-Son Nguyen and Kingsadingthongkham Vongdeth et al. published the classical synthesis of C-8-prenylated flavonoids using the 2,4,6-trihydroxyacetophenone as starting material ( Fig. 23 ) (Nguyen et al., 2015; Vongdeth et al., 2018 ). The methoxymethyl (MOM) group was chosen to protect hydroxy group on the benzene ring, under a series of reactions including aldol condensation, cyclization, oxidation with dimethyldioxirane (DMDO) and selective 5-demethoxymethyl protection yielding 3,7,4 ′ -tri- O -(methoxymethoxyl) kaempferol ( i1 ). Subsequently, the intermediate i1 was treated with prenyl bromide and K 2 CO
3 in
acetone at reflux, yielding the prenyl ether ( i2 ), following the microwave-assisted Claisen rearrangement in N , N -diethylaniline to obtain the desired para-prenylated flavonoid with 82% yield, which is the key step in the whole synthesis process. Besides, from the study of Elisa Nuti et al., while 5- O -prenylflavonoid was treated with N , N -dimethylaniline at 200 ◦ C without microwave irradiation, only 42% of the para-rearranged product was obtained and the ortho-rearranged product was found to be the major product ( Nuti et al., 2017 ). It suggested that the microwave irradiation plays a crucial role in the regioselective synthesis C-prenylated flavonoid.

caption.paragraph: The enzymatic activity of compounds against PDE4 (IC 50 , μM).

tableNote.paragraph: a Compounds with inhibition greater than 50% at 10 μM were further determined for corresponding IC values.
50 b Values are represented as means ± SD based on three independent experiments.

subSection.paragraph:
Furthermore, in order to address the poor selectivity of prenyl being rearrangement to flavonoids C-6 and C-8, Alberto Minassi et al. reported the method of straight synthesis of C-6 and C-8 prenylflavonoids via Wessely-Moser rearrangement ( Nicolaou et al., 2007 ; Khupse et al., 2007 ; Minassi et al., 2008 ). In spite of the fact that TBDMS group was more stable than other groups under the basic conditions [heating in toluene in the presence of Eu(fod) 3 ], thus, the TBDMS was chosen to protect the hydroxy group of 2,4,6-trihydroxyacetophenone ( Fig. 24 ). The intermediate i3 have been synthesized by Mitsunobu reaction, and it subsequently was treated with catalytic amounts of Eu(fod)
3 in
chloroform, Claisen-Cope product i4 was obtained in high yields through this method ( Gester et al., 2001 ). The key C-prenyl intermediate i4 was next pivaloylated to i5 and then chemoselectively ortho-desily lated by mild acidolysis with TFA in THF/water, affording the key C-prenyl intermediate
i 6
in excellent yield. Finally, under Brønsted acid catalysis and Wessely-Moser rearrangement, the key C-prenyl intermediates i4 and i6 are regioselectively converted to C-6 prenyl and C-8 prenyl flavones, respectively.

The development of a straightforward and tunable entry into C-6 and C-8 prenyl flavonoids from a common precursor would play a significant role in the field of biological activities of prenylated flavonoids. Recently, Wei Li and co-workers reported the regioselective syntheses of C-8 and C-6 prenyl substitution on flavonoids via intramolecular [1,3] or [1,5] shift reaction of 5- O -prenylflavonoids catalyzed by acidic clay (
Li et al., 2014 a
, 2019). Under the catalysis of Florisil clay in toluene, a series of C-8 prenyl flavonoids were obtained in good yields, and C-6 prenyl flavonoids were synthesized under the catalysis of Montmorillonite K10 clay, which started from commercially available and inexpensive precursor including diosmetin, quercetin and luteolin ( Fig. 25 ).

caption.paragraph: Fig. 21. Synthesis of prenylated flavonoids derivatives (551–563 ). Reagents and conditions: (a) Pd(OAc), AgAc, AcOH, dry toluene, N, 40 ◦ C, 8 h, 12–60%; (b) 2 2 SeO, 1,4-dixolane, 65 ◦ C, 2 h, 27%; (c) CH I, K CO, acetone, RT, 1 h, 87–94%; (d) butyldimethylsilyl-chloride, imidazole, dry CH Cl, RT, 12 h, 71%; (e) p - 2 3 2 3 2 2 bromobenzoyl/thiophene-2-carbonyl/acylchloride/tosyl/naphthalene-2-sulfonyl, dry pyridine, RT, 12 h, 73–82%; (f) 10% Pd/C, CH 2 Cl 2 , 10 h, 89%.
Fig. 22. Basic SARs studies of prenylated flavonoids with enzyme inhibitory activity.

heading.emphasis: 4.2. Total synthesis of B-ring prenylated flavonoids
4.3. Total synthesis of C-ring prenylated flavonoids

subSection.paragraph:
To the best of our knowledge, the majority of natural prenylated flavonoids are C-prenylated derivatives. Under the catalyzed action of regiospecific prenyltransferases, C-prenylation was generated frequently at position 6/8 on ring A or at position 3’/5 ′ on ring B, which are usually ortho to a phenolic hydroxyl group with rich electrons, and generated occasionally at C-3 on ring C, which is also more or less electron rich due to the conjugation ( Laflamme et al., 1993 ). Xu et al. reported a convenient route to direct synthesis of C-3 prenylated flavonoids. Alkylation of the key intermediate i16 with 3-methylbut-2-enyl bromide was carried out using LDA as the bases ( Fig. 27 ). Subsequent aldol condensations of i17 with various benzaldehydes were therefore carried out using NaHMDS in THF, and the chalcones i18 was synthesized. Finally, C-3 prenylated flavonoids were obtained by the cyclization with simultaneous deprotection under refluxing intermediate
i 18
in acid ( Sun et al., 2012 ; Tanaka et al., 2001 ; Xu et al., 2003 ).

caption.paragraph: Fig. 23. Synthetic route of C-8 prenylated flavonoids. Reagents and conditions: (a) CH 3 OCH 2 Cl, K 2 CO 3 , acetone, room temp., 83–90%; (b) 4-MOMO-benzaldehyde, KOH, EtOH, reflux, 85%; (c) I 2 , DMSO, reflux, 8 h, 70%; (d) oxone, acetone, CH 2 Cl 2 /NaHCO 3 / Na 2 CO 3 , RT; then p -toluenesulfonic acid, RT, 76%; (e) dilute HCl (aq.), EtOH, RT, 89%; (f) prenyl bromide, K 2 CO 3 , acetone, reflux, 95%; (g) microwave, PhNEt 2 , reflux, 82%. (h) H 2 SO 4 (20% aq.), CH 3 OH, reflux, 86%; (j) DDQ, 1,4-dioxane, reflux, 76%.

Fig. 24. Regioselective synthesis of C-6/C-8 prenylated flavonoids. Reagents and conditions: (a) TEA, TBDMS-Cl, H 2 SO 4 , dichloromethane, room temp., 83%; (b) Prenyl alcohol, TPP, DIAD, dichloromethane, ice bath, 56%; (c) Eu(fod), toluene, 140 ◦ C, 81%; (d) NaH, pivaloyl vanilloyl chloride (aq.), tetrahydrofuran, reflux, 3 85%; (e) CuCl, TMS-Cl, dry acetonitrile, RT, 60%; (f) i TBAF (aq.) dry tetrahydrofuran ii Pyrrolidine, H SO, 60%; (g) Pivaloyl chloride, DMAP, dry pyridine, 40 ◦ C, 2 2 4 15 min, H SO dilution; (h) TFA, dichloromethane, water, 30 ◦ C, 72%.

Fig. 25. Synthetic route of C-6/C-8 prenylated flavonoids from natural precusor. Reagents and conditions: (a) CH 3 OCH 2 Cl, K 2 CO 3 , acetone, RT; (b) prenyl bromide, K CO, acetone, 45 ◦ C; (c) Florisil, toluene, reflux; (d) Montmorillonite K10, toluene, reflux; (e) dilute HCl (aq.), CH OH, RT.
Fig. 26. The mechanism of synthesis B-ring prenylated flavonoids.

Fig. 27. Synthesis of C-3-prenylated flavonoids. Reagents and conditions: (a) CH OCH Cl, K CO, acetone 0 ◦ C, RT; (b) 3-methylbut-2-enyl bromide (2 equiv), fresh 3 2 2 3 LDA (2.5 equiv), THF, 75 ◦ C–4 ◦ C, 20 h, 50%; (c) ArCHO (2 equiv), NaHMDS (3 equiv), THF, 75 ◦ C to reflux, 30 h, 13–46%; (d) 4 N HCl, MeOH, reflux, 8–15 h, 22–63%.

subSection.paragraph: In this review, the research progress of biosynthesis, biological activities, semi- and fully synthesis of prenylated flavonoids was comprehensively summarized. Compelling evidences indicated that prenylation might increase the bioactivities of their backbone flavonoids. Therefore, prenylated flavonoids have the potential to be developed as new drugs or supplements. So far, a few prenylated flavonoids have been clinically studied, such as icaritin. From this perspective, prenylated flavonoids are good clues for drug discovery, which provides an opportunity to design more selective and active isoprene based prenylated flavonoids for the treatment of multifactorial diseases. Besides, the underlying action mechanisms and clinical studies of the prenylated flavonoids need to be explored in further studies.

subSection.paragraph: Shaochun Shi (born in 1996 in Hunan , China ) got his bachelor’ s and master’ s degree from Shenyang Pharmaceutical University in 2018 and 2021, respectively. His master thesis was studies on the structural modification and biological evaluation of flavonoids including prenylated flavonoids. He started to study for the PhD in Medicinal Chemistry at China Pharmaceutical University in 2021.

Jichong Li (born in 1997 in JiLin , China ) got his bachelor’ s from Changchun University of Chinese Medicine in 2019. He is studying for master’ s degree in Shenyang Pharmaceutical University. His master project was studies on the structural modification and biological evaluation of prenylated flavonoids including Icariin and Icaritin.

Xuemei Zhao (born in 1968 in Shenyang, China ) is an associate professor in School of Shenyang Pharmaceutical University.She worked as a translator for Year Book of Health People’ s Republic of China published by People’ s Medical Publishing House for twelve years successively, from 2006 to 2017. She proofread the English edition of some textbooks, including Experiments on Biochemistry and Molecular Biology. She is the part time English editor for Asian Journal of Social Pharmacy.

Dr. Qingbo Liu (born in 1984 in Shenyang, China ) is associate professor of School of Traditional Chinese Materia Medica, Shenyang Pharmaceutical University. He got M.Sc. and Ph.D in Natural Medicinal Chemistry from Shenyang Pharmaceutical University in 2010 and 2015 respectively. From 2016 to 2018, he worked as a postdoctoral researcher at ToHo University, Japan . His research interests include the isolation and structural modification of antiviral and antitumor active natural products.

Professor Shao-jiang Song (born in 1970 in Shenyang, China ) is the vice president in Shenyang Pharmaceutical University. Prof. Song performed his PhD in pharmaceutical chemistry 2000 at Shenyang Pharmaceutical University. Prof. Song has published > 200 SCI articles on medicinal plants chemistry for finding bioactive compounds as new anti-tumor and anti-AD medicine leads. He has conducted research on the prenylated flavonoids for up to 10 years and some studies are published in the journal including European Journal of Medicinal Chemistry, Journal of Natural Products, Scientific Reports, Chemico-Biological Interactions, Biomedicine & Pharmacotherapy, Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry Letters and so on.
